There is something very special in the way in which a Japanese
clings to his land. Wherever one goes in Japan* the tiniest
patch of land is treasured. Therefore, the immediate reaction
of the townsfolk against the Governments requisitioning order
was not merely apprehension concerning compensation# It Ytfas,
rather* absolute opposition to the idea of being deprived of
their land#
That*s right. Compensation is not the prime thing. But, did
you know it takes at least three months—and more often six
months before the compensation is actually paid in cash? When
a claim for compensation is put in, the appropriate authorities
from both sides have to start investigations into the cir¬
cumstances surrounding the accident, and it often happens that
trouble arises between the two sides in the course of such
investigations.
Another problem, more serious in one way than the ones we have
already dealt with, arises in the wake of 0fraternisation*
activities by American troops. The fault doubtless lies partly
in the fact that Japan has no definite laws dealing with the
question of prostitution. It also lies, however, in the
poverty which is as widespread as ever, and in the prevalence
of petty operators who will do anything to scrape together a
livelihood.
Yes, wherever there is an American base, women of a certain
type gather together in droves, and hastily improvise
amusement centres which spring up overnighta The problem of
such "fraternisation” is more difficult in Japan than in
European countries where American troops have be@n stationed*
This is doubtless due to racial differences and differences in
customs and ways of life, which are far more conspicuous here
than in Europe,
